content.title: Brédas, the haven of a passionate fine dining veteran

introduction.small: Martinique-born and bred Jean-Charles Brédas brings a simplicity and his own special twist to traditional dishes using organic, local ingredients.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Brédas, the haven of a passionate fine dining veteran

paragraphs.text:
After honing his craft at Le Relais de Sèvres in Paris – the fine dining restaurant at the former Sofitel Paris-Sèvres -, Jean-Charles Brédas decided to come home. At his restaurant in the small town of Saint-Joseph, around 10km to the north of Fort-de-France, he offers lovers of good food – locals and savvy tourists alike – a delicate fusion menu of complex, expertly-spiced and well-balanced dishes.

A little way outside the town centre in lush natural surroundings, the restaurant is welcoming, friendly, and full of warm wood tones. Once you are comfortably seated, and after the maestro has told you a passionate tale of his beginnings, things get serious: start with fritters as an amuse-bouche, or the spiced split pea soup. Then you might opt for the prawn galantine with bitter leaves and a Calypso dressing – unless of course, you are drawn in by the delicious compressed papaya with foie gras! All the vegetables are selected by Brédas himself at the Domaine de La Chabet organic market, which is why the menu changes depending on the day, the season, and the chef's mood.

As this poet of fine dining says himself, “To cook is to love: to love is to protect! To protect not only our planet and our biodiversity, but also – and most importantly – our temple: our body”. You heard it here first!

Brédas - L'Atelier du Briscard
Entrance on Presqu'île Rivière-Blanche
97212 Saint-Joseph

content.title: Rum tasting at Petibonum

introduction.small: On the Plage du Coin in Carbet, Le Petibonum sheds a light on Martinican heritage by way of the best agricultural rums of the island.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rum tasting at Petibonum

paragraphs.text:
The team behind Babaorum in Fort-de-France keeps on using Latin Roman connotations straight from the Astérix comic book series: Petibonum ("Litl'guy") is at the crossroads between beach restaurant and rum bar. Located on a private black sandy beach, the Plage du Coin in Carbet - halfway between Saint-Pierre and the Martinican administrative centre - it displays deck chairs either by the water or in the shade under a wooden structure, where you will be able to taste various local rums. Proud of his island, owner Guy Ferdinand, a local figure everyone sees coming in his tight shorts, has access to some of the very best distilleries on the island, including agricultural rums with a protected designation of origin (AOC Martinique). The island was first in line to create such a label for its agricultural rums, starting in the late 1990s! Take your pick among the varied selection, years, Grande Réserve, infused rums and cocktail specials with old rum and sugarcane… all to be enjoyed in moderation. As a token of quality, Petibonum was awarded best Caribbean bar by the Caribbean Journal in 2015, and it set up the first edition of the Martinique Rhum Awards in 2019.

From your bed, curtains pulled, the Fort-de-France Bay spreads as far as the eye can see. On Pointe Simon, near the Martinican capital's city centre, the Simon Hotel embodies modernity, showcasing refined design and lighting displays. Families are welcome and will be able to choose the apartment of their dreams for a stay with private terrace overlooking the sea and Française beach. The 4-star establishment entices you to stay in, providing a wellness centre and a restaurant popular across the whole island, thanks to starred chef Marcel Ravin. Back on his native island after a stint in Monaco among other places, he now heads up the hotel's fine dining restaurant, La Table de Marcel as well as Le Bistrot des Flamands", named after the gorgeous Flamands Bay (which is the Bay of Fort-de-France's alternate name). It opens when the sun sets in. Before dinner, or simply for drinks, stop by Le Bolibar and enjoy the terrace with a panoramic view. There, you will catch the most romantic sunsets ever.

content.title: Mount Pelée: watch out for the dormant volcano

introduction.small: At a height of 1,397m, Mount Pelée observes the sea with an Olympian calm. However, it is in fact a dormant volcano on the border of La Trinité and Saint-Pierre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mount Pelée: watch out for the dormant volcano

paragraphs.text:
From the beach, its green and mossy exterior provides it with the softness of a cradle of velvet that collects the heat of the sun at its centre. Nonetheless, the warm waters of its western flank remind Martiniquais that 'La Pelée' is indeed a volcano, and one with a dramatic past. One morning in May 1902, a powerful blast of air escaped and a pyroclastic flow, a gigantic toxic cloud, carried the dome of the volcano called Etang sec to the Rivère Blanche at more than 500km per hour. The crater then flared up. Within just a few minutes, the city of Saint-Pierre was destroyed and its 30,000 inhabitants succumbed to the wave of atmospheric shock, the inhalation of hot gases, the fall of volcanic blocks and the collapse of buildings.

Inactive since 1929 but monitored by the volcanic and seismological observatory of the island, Mount Pelée is now a place for hiking. On a clear day, you can plan a trip up to the summit accompanied by a guide and climb several hours from Prêcheur, the refuge of Aileron or through Beauséjour.

Mount Pelée

https://us.martinique.org/

content.title: Cap 110, in memory of the unknown

introduction.small: To the south of the island, the town of Le Diamant impresses tourists. Here you can visit the Anse Caffard Memorial, in the silence of a modest and dignified homage.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cap 110, in memory of the unknown

paragraphs.text:
On the coast of the Caribbean, 15 concrete statues face the sea, turned towards Cape 110: 15 colossal beings dressed in the whiteness of traditional graves. On 8 April 1830, a ship from the Gulf of Guinea dropped anchor off the coast of Le Diamant. The sea wind unleashed the swell and the foremast broke. Despite the ban on the slave trade, 300 slaves were chained to the bottom of the boat and tried to survive the sinking: there were just 86 survivors and only 46 bodies would be recovered.

On the occasion of the 150th anniversary of the abolition of slavery, the artist Laurent Valère created these imposing figures with their heads bowed, a symbol of the men trapped in the slave trade and caught by the sea when they tried to escape. The day after the tragedy, the bodies were buried at Anse Caffard. The eponymous memorial now tells the tragic story of these unknown men whose freedom was stolen from them.

Cap 110

content.title: The Bananeraie, a museum break

introduction.small: With this exotic address right next to the Banana Museum, Creole cuisine is revealed in a new light.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Bananeraie, a museum break

paragraphs.text:
Sainte-Marie is an ancient banana plantation that was turned into a museum dedicated to Martinican culture. After visiting the old mansion and vast shady park, a gourmet meal is required to digest everything you have just learned. The Banana Museum is a nice restaurant for 90 people, nestled in a typical Creole building that opens onto the surrounding lush nature. Being as it is on a former banana plantation, the chef serves local cuisine with a particular deference to bananas. The entire menu explores the possibilities of this fruit of the tropics, like ti-nain fritters, banana cassoulet and in lieu of apples in a tarte Tatin. The beverages follow suit, with a wide selection of cocktails, milkshakes and beer available - all to be enjoyed in moderation. Unusual and informative.

content.title: Les Salines: a picture-perfect postcard beach

introduction.small: Les Salines is the largest beach in Martinique and undoubtedly the most beautiful.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Salines: a picture-perfect postcard beach

paragraphs.text:
The beach of Salines on the southernmost tip of Martinique in the municipality of Sainte-Anne, has bright white sand and coconut palms tilting towards crystal clear waters. This is said to be the largest beach on the island – it stretches over a kilometre – but, more importantly, it is the most beautiful. It is also very busy, especially on weekends, so midweek visits are best if you want to fully enjoy the splendid location and avoid traffic on the way back. Explore the area all the way to the Salines pond, a protected ecosystem situated at the far end of the beach.

Local tradition has it that on Easter Monday, entire families come to enjoy a "crab matoutou", a delicious local recipe. After such a feast, if you are lucky enough to be invited to share this Martiniquais meal, do not hesitate to take the rocky path that leads to the Savannah of Petrifications, a former swamp that has dried up to become a desert with a curious lunar appearance.

content.title: The wrecks of Saint-Pierre: plunging into history

introduction.small: Many boats were anchored in the bay in 1902; now their wrecks lay 50m deep.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The wrecks of Saint-Pierre: plunging into history

paragraphs.text:
Many wrecks litter the bottom of the bay of Saint-Pierre, sunk by the eruption of Mount Pelée in 1902. Several diving clubs, like A Papa D'Lo Plongée Martinique, offer tours of the boats that sank in the waters of the Caribbean Coast.

Roraima, a Canadian cargo ship more than 100m long is a must. Captain Cousteau affectionately nicknamed it "the white-haired wreck" because of the algae that covers it. It burned for three days before it sank in 50m of water. A swim through the corridors and the engine room is included, but it is better to be accompanied by a professional. The Diamond, a steamship ferry that worked between Fort-de-France and Saint-Pierre, is also here. It has greatly deteriorated, with its disembowelled bow, and now rests in 25m of water that has become the haunt of vibrant sea life.

Another curiosity: Teresa Lo Vigo, a wooden sailboat with a copper-lined hull. You can still see part of the pottery cargo it was carrying. For all these discoveries, you must be an experienced diver. For beginners, the Amelia, a steel sailboat, is more accessible. It rests between 5 and 12m deep, and is now home to a colourful fish colony.

A Papa D'Lo Plongée Martinique

content.title: The Fort-de-France markets: a feast for the senses

introduction.small: Fragrant spices, colourful fruits and flowers…a visit to the Fort-de-France markets is a must. Why wait!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Fort-de-France markets: a feast for the senses

paragraphs.text:
Of course, the elders will tell you it was better before, that the animation and the spectacle are not what they used to be. But do not let their memories dissuade you: go along for a visit to the covered market, also known as the Grand Marché or spice market, whose colours and cries the writer Patrick Chamoiseau describes so aptly in one of his books, La Chronique des Sept Misères (The Chronicle of Seven Sorrows).

Stroll through the aisles, do not hesitate to ask for fruit and vegetables you do not recognise or whose names you do not know, delight in the colourful flowers, purchase a few spices.

The atmosphere on Creole markets is legendary, and such is the case at the "Man Zouzou" fish market, where fishmongers shout the name of their catch: king mackerel, bigeye scad mackerel and sauries, as well as small and large tuna! The Lafcadio Hearn market, meanwhile, is full of flower, fruit and vegetable stalls, even on Sunday.

content.title: The Jardin de Balata: a paradise of multi-coloured flowers

introduction.small: This botanical garden is home to hundreds of species of tropical plants, and a real treat for the eyes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Jardin de Balata: a paradise of multi-coloured flowers

paragraphs.text:
Ten kilometres north of Fort-de-France, you will find a beautiful botanical garden where more than 3,000 species of tropical plants flourish. It was created in 1986 through the efforts of Jean-Philippe Thoze, a passionate landscape horticulturist. At the time he bought this virtually neglected villa, the garden was uncultivated, and so he decided to restore it.

It has become a great success, with visitors flocking there to visit an unparalleled collection of flowers and trees. Hibiscus, anthurium, and porcelain roses in delicate shades may all be admired here. Less common essences such as heliconias, pandanus, and other more secret species may also be found.

Lastly, climb up to the treetops to take a walk between mahogany giants on suspended bridges more than 15m high. The view over the Bay of Fort-de-France and the Pitons du Carbet is magnificent.

content.title: The Yellow, really all yellow

introduction.small: A pleasant atmosphere with impeccable service, this small restaurant also offers excellent cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Yellow, really all yellow

paragraphs.text:
As the name suggests, yellow is everywhere you look here: from the fabric of the armchairs to the servers' ties. But whether you like flashy colours or not, there is no doubt you will enjoy this fun, friendly, first-floor restaurant. Fort-de-France locals – known as Foyalais – come here primarily for the cuisine, but also for the very warm welcome and impeccable service. Halfway between metropolitan gastronomy and local specialities, the chef prepares a creative and refined range of flavourful dishes made with fresh products, and elegantly presented. The compact menu changes regularly: one day it might be turbot in champagne, the next, a “giraumounade”, an oat risotto with deep-fried sea urchins. Even the bread is baked fresh on site. In the evening, the dishes are presented in a silver service, which adds to the chic atmosphere of the table.

Nights of full moon are an opportunity for thematic dinners - cuisine of yesteryears, wines from the Loire region, "from the Champagne region to the Antilles" - very popular in Fort-de-France. You could even leave with a few homemade products like fruit liquors or spicy oil.

content.title: Green Impérial: the best cocktails around

introduction.small: A Creole family pub where the king of all barmen mixes you delicious cocktails.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Green Impérial: the best cocktails around

paragraphs.text:
Regulars come to the Green Imperial to eat simple food made from very fresh local products, but they also come to sample the famous cocktails prepared by Thierry, a true veteran and master of original creations who was awarded best bartender in 1994.

With a big smile, he welcomes tourists and locals alike to this Creole family pub: his father and his grandmother before him held the reins of this hybrid grocery store/bar, called a "ti-lolo" in Creole. If you are staying in one of the hotels near Pointe du Bout, this is a great place to have a drink in a friendly, authentic atmosphere. Behind the bar, Thierry will be happy to introduce you to one of his creations, with or without alcohol, like the Green Team (orange and pineapple juices, coconut milk, mint syrup). Come on Friday if you wish to pair your cocktail with live music, played from Green Impérial's terrace.

content.title: The Babaorum: friendliness and good moods

introduction.small: The flavours of the food at this restaurant blend harmoniously with the sound of Caribbean music.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Babaorum: friendliness and good moods

paragraphs.text:
The former house of the grandmother of the current owner, Le Babaorum has been a restaurant that has exuded friendliness and good humour for nearly 20 years. The atmosphere is simple and relaxed, but that does not mean that quality suffers.

Pull up a chair at one of the tables set up on the cosy wooden deck, which also houses the bar. The cuisine is a multicultural, harmonious blend of metropolitan and Caribbean flavours. As a starter, choose a fried Camembert, before savouring a delicious, freshly caught fish. Swordfish and ouassous (crayfish) with spicy sauce are highly popular among guests, but remember to leave room for dessert, as the choice is prodigious. Every Thursday evening, music lovers meet up at the Babaorum, which is also famous for its live music.

And one last tip: remember to turn off your cell phone, which is prohibited here. If it does ring, it could cost you a bottle of champagne, undoubtedly accompanied by the gladdened smiles of your neighbours.

High up in an apricot tree, accessible by a cable bridge, is the tree house of your dreams. From its terrace nestled in the branches, you can enjoy an unparalleled view of the beach and the transparent sea.

Enjoy this cosy nest to relax and enjoy the simple joys of a drink at sunset, all while admiring the grace of a butterfly flying from flower to flower. Please note that as a safety precaution, children are not permitted access to the tree house. If you stay as a family, you should favour the "bigbung", a two-bedroom bungalow with a large terrace located only 30m from the beach of Anse noire. The suites in the main building, with names taken from French candies (nougat, Tagada strawberry, or liquorice, etc.), offer a magnificent view of the ocean. The bungalows built on the hillside contain one, two, or three rooms, and are fitted with a Jacuzzi and a hammock on the terrace. All one needs to spend a perfect family holiday.

The Zandoli, the hotel restaurant, offers refined dishes created in collaboration with the highly respected starred-chef of Saint-James restaurant in Bordeaux Nicolas Magie. Dining on the terrace in the evening, the illuminated view over Fort-de-France Bay is magical.

content.title: Lili's Beach: beach bar

introduction.small: Savour every moment until the end of the night with your feet in the sand and your head cooled by the salt air.

Her name is Lisa, but regulars call her Lili, hence the name of this cosy beach restaurant, which she runs with her brother.

Located at the foot of the La Batelière Hotel, north of Fort-de-France, it has become a very popular hangout for young people. The atmosphere is hip and relaxed from morning to night. The many cocktails for which the bartender is renowned throughout the Caribbean are sipped to the rhythm of the music 'til midnight during the week, but until 3:00 a.m. on weekends. The menu offers tuna and sea bream tartare and carpaccio, grilled fish, burgers and "skizzas", crispy pizzas made without yeast, a pure delight. Particular attention is paid to environmental preservation and respect of Martinican heritage. Lili uses daily and local products. And every morning, the restaurant staff endeavours to clean up the beach. A real and committed must-go-to of a place.

content.title: Habitation Clément, the manor house

introduction.small: This is one of the finest properties on Martinique, surrounded by a beautiful garden. Come here to learn all about the secrets of the rum trade.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Habitation Clément, the manor house

paragraphs.text:
Out of an old house in disrepair, its owners who bought it in 1986 have made a superb colonial mansion visited annually by more than 200,000 people. Moreover, this is the only Creole house open to the public. More than a mere building, a "house" in Martinique pertains to the whole domain, from sugarcane fields to exploitation structures and the main house. In the latter, you will find the historical headquarter of Clément rums.

Its claim to fame: hosting the Franco-American summit in 1991 when François Mitterrand and US President George Bush had the opportunity to meet after the Gulf War.

Listed as a historical monument in 1996 and completely restored in 2002, Habitation Clément allows you to understand the making of rum from cane cultivation to its aging over several years in wooden barrels, expertise that has carried on for decades and that each producer keeps jealously secret.

content.title: Îlet Oscar: the feeling of being a castaway on one's own island

introduction.small: Playing Robinson Crusoe is fun – but doing it while enjoying refined, eco-friendly comfort is even better.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Îlet Oscar: the feeling of being a castaway on one's own island

paragraphs.text:
This is a unique place where you can make time stand still with a fabulous getaway: imagine an authentic wooden Creole house, alone on a tiny islet. Better yet, this house, listed as a historical monument, has only four rooms, all facing the sea, each with a private bathroom.

Getting there is simple: when you arrive in François, a fisherman welcomes you aboard his skiff. Along the way he tells you the story of the house. Originally built in the 19th century on a neighbouring islet, the owner lost it in a card game. After being dismantled, it was rebuilt on Oscar Islet and reopened in 1935. It has retained the character of its time, along with some beautiful antique furniture, but it has also gained in comfort.

Environmental concerns are at the fore with regular use of solar panels and water heaters, wastewater treatment and rainwater tanks. Robinson Crusoe's dream paradise, indeed…and eco-friendly, too.

content.title: Maison La Mauny distillery: white and amber rum

introduction.small: To learn some rum trade secrets, you simply must visit the Maison La Mauny distillery.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Maison La Mauny distillery: white and amber rum

paragraphs.text:
Martinique is the land of rum. Take the opportunity to visit a distillery to introduce yourself to the production of this drink, which should obviously be consumed in moderation. In the south of the island, Maison La Mauny is one of the distilleries open for visits.
During the tour (on board a little train), you will follow the stages that lead from the sugar cane fields to orange groves and the ancient master's house of the domain. You will learn about the different stages necessary to create the famous eau-de-vie: cutting of the canes, manufacturing processes of fermentation, distillation, assembly, and finally aging in oak barrels. Out of this comes the rum - white, amber, or one of the prestige brands that are the hallmark of producers.
This domain was founded here more than three centuries ago, when a young nobleman from Brittany, Ferdinand Poulain, Count de Mauny, married the daughter of a wealthy planter from Rivière Pilote. The Bellonie family bought the property in the 1920s and since then it has been modernised and expanded. Since 1996, Maison La Mauny rum has a protected designation of origin (AOC).

The charm of the Hotel Plein Soleil is in its tropical garden, amidst which are found 15 rooms and suites in five traditional Creole houses. Perched on the heights of the town of François, this three-star hotel is bathed by refreshing trade winds.

Choose from a range of 30 sqm contemporary rooms, 96 sqm garden suites, or significantly larger 116 sqm duplex apartments to suit you. Take advantage of your stay to go walking on the hiking trails of the regional park on the Caravelle peninsula.

It is also possible to visit a rum distillery, like Neisson, Depaz, or St. James, among others, who will help you better understand this captivating island drink (taken in moderation, of course).

It offers 96 simple but welcoming rooms. Some even have a kitchenette for those who desire a longer stay. The Palm Bar, decorated with palm leaves, of course, is there to serve you a drink with your feet in the water. If you are dreaming of the seabed, scuba diving classes for beginners are also available upon request. Just ask the front desk!

After a day that combines relaxation and discovery, dine on dishes at the restaurant that blend Creole flavours and other cuisines with talent and sensitivity. A great place for families with small children, as those under 4 stay for free.

content.title: Le Kano: lounge chairs by the sea

introduction.small: Creole cuisine to be enjoyed by the sea, with music to accompany your meal.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Kano: lounge chairs by the sea

paragraphs.text:
The Kano is a popular lounge-style restaurant on Anse Mitan with refined decor and the beach at your feet. Upon entering, relax in a deep armchair behind a turquoise barrier that resembles the sea. The walls are decorated with works from local artists and exhibitions change regularly.

After working in several hotels, Christophe Lupon bought the Kano in 2012 and since then has continued to invest in improvements. Chef Maryline Etilé creates Creole cuisine with specialties that invite one to gourmandise, such as honey-ginger duck breast, sweet potato flan, and candied sweet chilli conch. At the cocktail hour, nestle gently in a lounge chair placed by the shore, sip a cocktail best paired with a few Caribbean tapas like the avocado féroce or the pink tuna skewers à la Créole, and relax to the soft soothing music.

Let yourself be carried away by the quintessential charm of the Antilles...

content.title: Club Med Les Boucaniers: a sportsman's paradise

introduction.small: A sportsman's paradise indeed, but also for all those who have come to rest and enjoy a well-deserved vacation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Club Med Les Boucaniers: a sportsman's paradise

paragraphs.text:
It is well known that Club Med has always targeted the most beautiful locations. When it set up its Buccaneers village in 1969, at a time when there were few hotels on Martinique, this specialist in holiday villages chose this stunning location, between the Anses d'Arlet and the Pointe des Salines in southern Martinique.

A few years ago, the village underwent a complete renovation of its 289 rooms, which include 44 suites, spread between sea and tropical garden. Although comfort has always been its calling card, many people come to enjoy the many sports on offer: sailing, diving, surfing, water skiing, etc.

For lunch and dinner, you can choose between the main restaurant and its sumptuous buffets, or the more intimate restaurant (only 70 seats, by reservation) at one end of the village. Back in your room, you can have fun trying to translate the Creole proverb displayed above your bed.

content.title: Clément Foundation: a superb painting exhibition

introduction.small: An enchanting setting to discover the many Caribbean artists.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Clément Foundation: a superb painting exhibition

paragraphs.text:
Because he is passionate about art, but also because he wanted to help local painters too often ignored by their contemporaries, Bernard Hayot, head of the GBH Group (car import, retail, industry, etc.) has evolved into a patron of the arts.

In the 2000s, he began restoring the buildings around the Habitation Clément, a huge domain overlooked by a splendid Creole mansion from the 18th century, to provide unwavering support to the artists of the Caribbean and the Indian Ocean. Particularly supportive of contemporary Caribbean art, the Clément Foundation has organised more than 170 exhibitions (visits are free) amidst this unique site of Martinican heritage. Since the opening of a modern new building in 2016, leaning against the old vat room, the Clément Foundation has become a major cultural centre on the island. Enjoy the visit and discover the Clément distillery museum on the way, dedicated to agricultural rum making.

content.title: Domaine Saint Aubin: love at first sight

introduction.small: A taste of the grand mansions of yesteryear, and an ideal place for romantics.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Domaine Saint Aubin: love at first sight

paragraphs.text:
The Domaine Saint Aubin, near the town of Sainte-Marie is a beautiful house with architecture inspired by colonial houses as seen in Gone with the Wind. Featuring period furniture, mahogany parquet flooring, terraces, a flowered garden where mango, lemon and avocado trees thrive, it exudes a romantic atmosphere that appeals to all.

The owners, a couple who fell in love with this place after it had been on sale for a good ten years, have named each room after an opera, from Puccini's Madame Butterfly to Verdi's Il Trovatore. On the second floor, the old attic has been converted into charming mansard rooms with exposed beams.

The estate is equipped with various lodges as well as a small villa that all offer hotel services identical to the rooms of the manor: refined decoration, mahogany furniture in the bathroom and large colonial bed.

After an afternoon at the beach, or the exploration of the northern part of the island - make sure to push on as far as Grand'Rivière in the far north, a true wonder - you will relax in the summer lounge, where you can watch the sun set slowly on the horizon.

content.title: A stroll around Saint-Pierre: souvenirs of a volcanic eruption

introduction.small: Here, the visitor has an appointment with history, for in 1902 the volcano destroyed the town, which is re-born today.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A stroll around Saint-Pierre: souvenirs of a volcanic eruption

paragraphs.text:
Saint-Pierre was the economic and cultural centre of Martinique for a long time, inhabited by a rich bourgeoisie who grew powerful over centuries thanks to the sugar industry. Its port was one of the busiest in the Caribbean…until May 8, 1902. That day, an eruption of Mount Pelée, the volcano that dominates the city from a height of 1397m, destroyed all that was sweet in life.

The pyroclastic flow caused the deaths of 26,000 people, destroyed thousands of homes, and sank around 40 boats in the harbour. Saint-Pierre was wiped off the map of communities before being re-born decades later. Now a city of art and history, it is looking to its past, which it is patiently restoring.

Here you can survey the streets, visit the cathedral, the ruins of the Colonial House of Health and those of the theatre, built, it was said, on the model of that of Bordeaux. You can also see the cell where the fortunate prisoner Cyparis was locked up: he was one of only two survivors of the eruption, with the thick prison walls protecting him from the flow.

content.title: Vauclin Mountain, an incredible place

introduction.small: The trail follows the stations of the cross, but you will be dazzled by the view when you get to the top.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vauclin Mountain, an incredible place

paragraphs.text:
The reward is at the top, near the Chapel of Our Lady of Sorrows (aptly named) with a view that is ablaze with the vast panorama of pointed bays from the Caravelle peninsula to Sainte-Anne.

At 504m, Vauclin Mountain is the highest point in southern Martinique. You reach it via the small road that goes to Saint-Esprit. Though the hike is fairly easy, it is best to forego the sandals and wear proper footwear, as the slope may be slippery, especially if it has rained recently.

Along the trail, you will come across richly varied vegetation that will make you almost think you are in a botanical garden. There are mango and breadfruit trees, and bright red flowers everywhere. Benches may be found along the way that offer welcome respite, because the route is practically a real -life Way of the Cross, dotted with numbered white crosses to mark the pilgrim-hiker's progress.
